name: 2-bromo-1,1-difluoroethane
Reason: The basic unit, ethane, has a melting point of -183.0 °C. The introduction of each halogen typically raises the melting point because of increased molecular weight and stronger intermolecular forces such as London dispersion forces and, in the case of bromine, dipole-dipole interactions. A bromine atom should have a large effect due to its significant size and electronegativity, potentially raising the melting point by roughly +75°C per bromine atom. Each fluorine atom is smaller than bromine and would have a lesser effect, estimated at around +10°C per fluorine atom. So, ΔT_bromine = +75°C, ΔT_fluorine(each) = +10°C.

name: 2-bromo-1,1-difluoroethane
Reason: The basic unit, ethane, has a melting point of -183.0 °C. The addition of a bromine atom significantly increases the melting point due to greater molecular weight and enhanced intermolecular interactions such as London dispersion forces and dipole-dipole interactions. We can estimate this increase to be around +70°C for a bromine atom. Each fluorine atom introduces smaller increases due to its smaller size but still contributes to a higher melting point through enhanced molecular weight and dipole interactions, with an estimated increase of around +16°C per fluorine atom. So for the bromine, ΔT_bromine = +70°C, and for each fluorine, ΔT_fluorine = +16°C.

name: 2-bromo-1,1-difluoroethane
Reason: The basic unit, ethane, has a melting point of -182.8°C. The addition of halogen substituents to a hydrocarbon generally increases the melting point due to the higher molecular weight and stronger intermolecular forces (van der Waals and possible dipole-dipole interactions). Each fluorine adds more electronegativity difference creating a polarity to the molecule: +40°C for each fluorine due to the increased dipole moments and molecular weight. Bromine, being larger, contributes more significantly, increasing the melting point by another +60°C due to its larger size, increased van der Waals forces and polarizability. These increases are cumulative.

name: 2-bromo-1,1-difluoroethane
Reason: The basic unit, ethane, has a melting point of -182.8°C. The addition of halogen substituents to a hydrocarbon generally increases the melting point due to the higher molecular weight and stronger intermolecular forces (van der Waals and dipole-dipole interactions). Each fluorine adds to the melting point due to increased electronegativity, which leads to stronger dipole-dipole interactions: we estimate +20°C for each fluorine. Bromine, being larger than fluorine, contributes even more significantly, increasing the melting point by +40°C due to its greater size leading to increased van der Waals forces and polarizability. These effects are cumulative.

name: 2-bromo-1,1-difluoroethane
Reason: Starting with ethane, which has a melting point of -172 degrees Celsius, we consider the effects of the substituents. Bromine is a large, heavy atom that increases the polarizability and molecular weight, so it raises the melting point significantly. A bromine substituent can increase the melting point by roughly +60 to +80 degrees. On the other hand, fluorine atoms are highly electronegative; they increase the polarity of the molecule which can lead to stronger dipole-dipole interactions, but they are also smaller than bromine and thus have less of an effect on the melting point. Each fluorine might raise the melting point by approximately +5 to +10 degrees. Considering there are two fluorine atoms, their combined effect might be around +10 to +20 degrees.
